docs.text:
EH-v uh (/ˈɛ.va/) - like in pEt, Very, Up

EVA is a 3D printing carriage platform revolving around accessibility - the goal is to give the power of choice to the users by enabling as many options for carriage hardware as possible. The "platform" part means a few things, for one EVA is a specification - a 3D printer can be EVA compatible (not the other way around - EVA is not to be compatible with a printer) thus automatically acquiring all the hardware compatibility EVA brings and will bring in it's future versions. New versions appear with compatibility for new hardware. Aside from being a spec, EVA also comes with a set of parts ready to use on compatible printers.

EVA is developed by me - Paweł Kucmus and the fantastic EVA and Rat Rig community.

EVA 2.4.2

If you are looking for the old version of EVA, it's here: https://2.eva-3d.page/
docs.title: EVA

docs.text: Navigate to the Getting Started page to learn where to start. If you know your way around this place already and just looking for a download link you will find it below. Either way please read further down to learn about the people behind EVA.
docs.title: Getting started

docs.text: Best way to see what is new is to attend the live streams on YouTube.
docs.title: Updates

docs.text:
My and EVA's relationship with Rat Rig should not be a surprise as I'm also responsible for V-Core 3, V-Minion and V-Core Pro 1.2 and up. Rat Rig was and still is providing me with an amazing support in terms of hardware, guidance and emotional support

All of their printers are EVA compatible.
docs.title: Rat Rig

docs.text:
The nature of EVA is specific in a way that I always did shy away from any free parts producers were willing to send me. If I got something for free it was immediately sent to one of the beta testers. This is to prevent accusations towards the platform for being biased.

There is no way of purchasing a spot here.

That said if this will change and I'll start receiving parts it will not be a secret and I'll probably list those on one of the release lives on YouTube.
docs.title: Other companies

docs.text:
Mikkel Schmidt and Marc Marschall constantly pushed for more improvements, took some of the work of my shoulders - big thank you. Simon Davie is helping out for as long as I can remember, printer compatibility would not ba as good if not for Simon's checks.

There's also a big group of people that helped out with beta testing, they had to go through a lot of work and plastic to test all the different iterations that I was producing when fixing more and more bugs - amazing bunch of people.
docs.title: People

docs.text: If you need a more direct contact I'm (McAbra#1650) on the Rat Rig Unofficial Discord Server along with many awesome people that will surely help 😄
docs.title: Contact

docs.text: EVA is named after my wife Ewa (polish Eve) you read it like: EH-v uh (/ˈɛ.va/) - like in pEt, Very, Up.
docs.title: How to pronounce EVA?

docs.text:
Sure, I'm not much of a drinker though, I also only drink coffee at home. But if you want to support this work of mine you can use the Paypal.me link. The money I gather there I spend on parts, filament and stuff I generally need to use when testing EVA.

Sadly, there is no other way to sponsor EVA as platform like Patreon can't be used with the broken polish tax system... (rant redacted)
docs.title: Can I buy you a beer?

docs.text:
Remix this model on printables.com.

The rules are:

  1. follow the License - to name a few:
    1. attribute
    2. release under the same license
  2. do not remove any of the EVA logos from the parts
docs.title: How can I contribute or make derivatives / remixes

docs.text: Here: printables.com I'm thinking about something like the old contrib page that would require less maintenance.
docs.title: Contributions? Where to put them?

docs.text: As long as it's not purple it's fine. As everyone knows black color is the strongest but green is the fastest EVA is black/green so we have the benefits of both ;)
docs.title: What color scheme can be used?

docs.text: It's too much work for me to maintain to rotate it all, either it's going to be a post-process thing I can figure out or we are stuck with how it is. You can find a preview of the orientation in the getting started page.
docs.title: What is the print orientation and why are the STLs not in the right one?

docs.text: It depends, better for what? One of the design goals was to have the motor on top of the MGN carriage, as it weights the most. From there we go down to the nozzle tip, having different sized hotends to support there has to be an interface "layer" between the two. Once you'll use it you will likely forget that this ever bothered you - that's how it was for many users since EVA 1.0.
docs.title: Wouldn't it be better to attach the hotend directly to the extruder?

docs.text: I don't remember.
docs.title: Why did you did it like that?

docs.text: I don't want to talk about it :}
docs.title: No, seriously why?

docs.text:
No, for my own reasons EVA 3 will not support the Dragon hotend officially and the only entity that can change that is the company that is producing it. This is not about the other company or patents that work worldwide or not - this is about my rules that I want to follow (this time).

Same goes for clones, those are important for beginners but again - I would not feel OK supporting those.
docs.title: Dragon support? Clones in general?

docs.text: There are many projects that came from the same family as EVA. Check them out for the full experience :)
docs.title: Ecosystem

docs.text:
A CoreXY 3D printer design from Rat Rig, where I am one of the main developers. Fully compatible with EVA.

V-Core 3 page
docs.title: V-Core 3

docs.text:
A cantilevered, cartesian style printer with 1803 print volume, I'm on the development team of that one as well. Fully compatible with EVA.

V-Minion page
docs.title: V-Minion

docs.text:
A Klipper-based "firmware bundle" created and maintained by Mikkel Schmidt.

RatOS allows you to quickly install the firmware for your printer, without the need to learn the very technical details of Klipper. This bundle contains presets not only for the printers listed above (and more) but also for the specific EVA variants. This is also where you can find different wiring diagrams.

RatOS page
docs.title: RatOS

docs.text:
Just here for the files?

In that case navigate to heat inserts or hex nuts sections.

EVA might look intimidating at first but it's really not, sure the BOMs are complicated and you need to learn yourself around all this but think about it like this:
docs.title: Getting started

docs.text: As for print settings I made them work for up to a 0.5 nozzle, although you might need to enable thin walls detection in your slicer then printing with a 0.5 nozzle. Aside from that you want ~1mm of perimeters (i.e. 2 perimeters with a 0.55mm perimeter width, or 3 perimeters with a 0.45mm perimeter width). As for infill 15% is enough.
docs.title: Printing

docs.text: Even thought EVA 3 is a major version jump from EVA 2 a lot a work was put to achieve as much backwards compatibility, below you'll find information about specific printer compatibility:
docs.title: Printer compatibility

docs.text:
The X endstop block needs to change - get taller, also you will likely need longer belts if you cut them short - close to the carriage.

I'm working on it.
docs.title: V-Core 3

docs.text:
Almost there, sensorless homing should work, otherwise the X motor block on VM will need to be adjusted.

I'm working on it.
docs.title: V-Minion

docs.text: Not yet, but the port should be similar to VC3.
docs.title: V-Core Pro >= 1.2

docs.text: Not, depending on the demand and time I might port it but his will require some work.
docs.title: V-Cast

docs.text:
Let's define the 4 main components as the Core, this would be:

  • Top - interface between the MGN12 and the rest of EVA
  • Front - universal interface for hotend mounts
  • Bottom - support piece integrated with an cooling duct option
  • Back - different backs are use for different motion systems
docs.title: Core

docs.text: The component that goes on top of the top and front parts - specific to your chosen extruder option.
docs.title: Drive

docs.text: Component wrapping the hotend around provided mounting for the hotend fan and interfaces with the front part.
docs.title: Hotend

docs.text: Component specific to your layer cooling fan option, attaches to the back.
docs.title: Cooling Inlet

docs.text: Provides means to attach or organize cables routed to the carriage, attaches to the back.
docs.title: Cable Management

docs.text: Goes on the front allows to mount the bed probe of your choosing.
docs.title: Bed Probe

docs.text:
You will need one piece of a PTFE tube going from the drive to the hotend. The length of that tube is different for each drive and hotend combo. To learn how much PTFE you need you can take a look at the BOM tables of you chosen drive and hotend and sum the two values (do not cut into two pieces).

below is an example of the Nova hotend and LGX as the drive. Nova needs 39.65 mm to the "roof" of the universal front, LGX needs 20.8 mm which gives us 60.45 mm. Those are the measurements taken from CAD, in the real world there's usually a 0.2mm difference. A good way to measure exactly is to assemble everything and put the PTFE cut to the calculated length into the hotend so it already goes through the top of the universal face and down the the heat break, then put your drive assembly on top and shave off any amount that is too long. You don't have to be super precise there.
docs.title: PTFE Lenghts

docs.text:
Use the navigation on the left (or in the top left menu on small screens) to navigate through the heat insert parts. Those are recommended for parts printed with ASA and ABS.

The insert size EVA is modeled for is M3 x D4.6 x L4.0 but this does not have to be exact, i.e. D5.0 or L5.0 inserts should work as well, just might require a bit of clean up of the plastic that's pushed out.
docs.title: Heat Inserts

docs.text:
Use the navigation on the left (or in the top left menu on small screens) to navigate through the hex nuts parts. Those are easier to assemble if you don't have experience with heat inserts, hex nuts are also cheaper and easier to come by.

Then inserting the nuts into their sockets you should use the "backpull" method. Thread a screw through the hole, add a nut on the screw and pull the nut in by screwing it in. This will ensure your nut is aligned correctly - failing to to so carries the risk of a screw binding in a nut mid-assembly rendering your build trash.

Hex nuts also require plenty of sacrificial layers, those are simple to remove, poke them out with a screwdriver or drill out.
docs.title: Hex Nuts

docs.text:

docs.text:
Cooling

Due to how the Mosquito heat block shape is it's difficult for EVA to achieve proper cooling. You might want to look at the Tri Horn duct to improve the cooling performance.

docs.title: Chonkier

docs.text: Chonkier is the same as Chonky but with extra features added. Personally, I don't like it, but it depends on one's taste when it comes to those os I'm leaving it, maybe you'll like it :). I made variants with probe cut outs in case stuff like BL-Touch would not fit.

docs.title: Chonky

docs.text: Chonky is a tall and light shroud that was the first shroud I made for EVA 3.0. It offers some possibility for a tidy build as you can hide some wires behind it (especially the ADXL ones). Comes with a version for those who tend to shove their allen keys in the spinning fan blades.
docs.title: Description

For chonky

docs.title: Tank

docs.text:
Tank shroud is a shroud I envisioned being "the V-Core 3 shroud" - big and tanky, hides a 8mm probe inside.

Caveats:

  • it only supports 8mm probes
  • it's thick in Y so a 4020 might not work with it in all applications

docs.text:
Tank shroud is a shroud I envisioned being "the V-Core 3 shroud" - big and tanky, hides a 8mm probe inside.

Caveats:

  • it only supports 8mm probes
  • it's thick in Y so a 4020 might not work with it in all applications
docs.title: Description

docs.text:
For tank

Item Quantity Name Printable 1 1.0 shroud_tank yes
docs.title: Bill of Materials

docs.text:
STEP files? CAD Link?

If you are looking for the CAD link to tamper with the design or to export the parts in formats other than STL you can find the links below. Be warned though! The link directs to a live - bleeding edge - version of this particular EVA module - there is no promise it will be the same version as what you see above nor does it have to be the version Rat Rig provides.

I understand, please give me the link
